repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Palestinian Expatriate
            Professional Program

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the Palestinian
            Expatriate Professional Program were as follows: the outcome
            was unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was negligible, and the
            Bank and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory.
            Lessons learned: Projects in a development in conflict or
            politically dynamic context have different start-up
            considerations to 'normal' projects. Such projects
            should also incorporate a strong monitoring system to adapt
            to changing circumstances. Human resource projects of this
            kind (where senior staff are 'parachuted in') are
            both institutionally sensitive and complex to implement.
            Expatriate recruitment projects would also be more effective
            as part of a broader capacity building strategy based on
            institutional assessments of need. High risk projects should
            build in a risk mitigation strategy. Operating policies and
            procedures should be tested during the pilot phase and then
            reviewed in light of the lessons learnt.

5087487.trustfund:
TF027041-PALESTINIAN EXPATRIATE
            PROFESSIONAL PROGRAM (PEPP),TF026042-PALESTINIAN EXPATRIATE
            PROFFESSIONALS PROGRAM

repnme.cdata!:
West Bank and Gaza - Palestinian Expatriate
            Professional Program Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Palestinian
            Expatriate Professional Program Project are to: (1) attract
            skilled and experienced managers and senior technical
            specialists from the Palestinian diaspora to fill management
            and technical positions in key Palestinian ministries and
            agencies; (2) establish a transparent, independent, and
            international recruitment process to fill these positions;
            and (3) help establish compensation practices based on
            objective criteria and a transparent methodology. This
            project supports the Bank's overall objective of
            building policy-making and institutional capacity within the
            Palestinian government. The project will finance relocation
            allowances and local government salaries for Palestinian
            expatriates and a contract with a leading international
            management consulting firm to implement the project.
